title: 87 Cellphone Abbreviations You Can Use To Text...
text:
By Gerald Erichsen Updated October 19, 2015 . 
Despite glaring limitations, such as tiny screens and cumbersome keyboards, cellphones have become an immensely popular tool for sending messages. 
Sending messages in Spanish can pose extra challenges, as typing accented letters and Spanish punctuation isn't always intuitive. But these limitations haven't prevented cellphone chat — technically known in both English and Spanish as SMS (for Short Message Service) — from becoming useful for Spanish speakers worldwide. ( SMS in Spanish is pronounced as would be esemese .) 
One way of overcoming some of the phone's limitations is the use of abbreviations and word or symbol substitutions to get the message across in fewer keystrokes. In Spanish, many of the shorter words used are phonetic usages, such as q for que or qué (the name of the letter is pronounced the same as the word) and the elimination of the letter h , which is silent . Some of the cellphone words are also carryovers from computer chat conventions, such as the use of " :) " to indicate happiness. 
continue reading below our video What are the Seven Wonders of the World A few anglicisms are also common. 
Cellphone abbreviations are far from standardized, but here are some of them you may come across or want to try using yourself: 
100pre — siempre — always
